awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Water treatment technology to remove arsenic from contaminated groundwater
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of a water treatment technology that may produce arsenic-free drinking water for small, low-income rural communities. About 200 million individuals are exposed to high levels of arsenic through their drinking water. Arsenic is a naturally occurring groundwater contaminant and causes the most excess cancers of any regulated carcinogenic water contaminant at its permitted level. The proposed technology may benefit small communities with a water quality problem that up until now may have been too expensive to address at small scale. Although other arsenic-removal technologies exist, their unit costs rise rapidly at small scale, leaving many communities potentially unable to afford operation and maintenance of such plants once they have been built. In addition, the proposed technology also may help alleviate the burden placed on health care systems for costs associated with arsenic-related cancers, which ranges between $75,000 to $150,000 per person in the United States. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology for remediation of arsenic contamination of water. This proposed electrochemical technology removes arsenic by releasing in the water iron rust that first binds to arsenic and is subsequently removed through filtration or settling. The proposed technology may remove high concentrations of arsenic from groundwater down to levels consistently below the EPA-approved maximum level of 10 ppb. The advantages of the proposed technology over current arsenic removal technologies include possible better efficacy of arsenic removal, potentially lower capital and operating and maintenance costs, requires less labor, and could eliminate the production of any liquid waste stream.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public (POR)

Through the generous support of the NSF I-Corps program,  JuvenAqua (Team 2793) is further maturing a water-treatment technology to market.  The technology aims to rapidly remove arsenic from contaminated groundwater used for drinking. Our project aims to help the 220 million people around the world who drink water contaminated with arsenic, a known poison, which can cause catastrophic health consequences. This water treatment technology has numerous advantages over current technologies for small-community applications.  These advantages include cost, effectiveness, and scalability, for removing arsenic from drinking water for small rural communities.

Intellectual Merits

Conventional arsenic treatment methods typically require pre-treatment, chemical addition, and generate significant amounts of arsenic-laden liquid waste, whose safe disposal is expensive. They also require a trained operator to deploy them.  In contrast, our technology (based on iron electrocoagulation) rapidly captures and immobilizes arsenic from water on to iron rust particles, and then the solid sludge that can be removed and landfilled without further treatment steps. By reducing the amount of waste generated, our technology addresses one of the largest pain points and costs associated with the existing technologies in use today for arsenic removal from drinking water. The fast chemical kinetics of our treatment technology also allow our treatment unit to have a very small footprint compared to that of technologies with slower kinetics. This technology represents a substantial leap forward in electrochemical water treatment and sustainable water management, contributing to the broader scientific understanding of how we can more efficiently deliver potable water to small communities. The technology is also more easily amenable to automation and minimum operator presence, thus reducing labor costs.

The technology our team is currently developing is a next generation product for arsenic-removal, a topic that has been studied in the Gadgil Lab for Energy and Water Research at UC Berkeley since 2006, under the supervision of our project PI, Dr. Ashok Gadgil (Distinguished Professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering & a Faculty Senior Scientist in the Energy Technologies Area at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory).

 

Broader Impacts

Lifelong consumption of drinking water with Arsenic contamination at its MCL, leads to the most excess cancers compared to similar exposure to any other carcinogen in water at its MCL. Some states have already established stricter limits on allowable maximum concentration of arsenic in drinking water than that allowed by the EPA.  However many existing arsenic-removal technologies are unable to meet those lower treatment goals. Our technology specifically targets arsenic removal down to concentrations ten times lower than what is allowed by the EPA.

About 10 million people in the US, and about 220 million people worldwide are exposed to arsenic in their drinking water above the MCL of 10 ppb. Most of this population is from small rural communities. Throughout this project, we formed partnerships with farming communities in the rural Central Valley of California which will eventually serve as demonstration sites. 

In future, we expect to help one community with a pilot demonstration site to exchange knowledge with other communities experiencing similar water quality challenges. Our arsenic-removal water treatment technology strives to benefit the portion of society (in small rural communities) unfairly burdened with a water quality problem that up until now has been considered too expensive to address.
